facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 358 and 359 of 1957 are appeals by special leave from the judgment and decree dated April 4, 1956, of the Patna High Court in M. J. C. Nos. 546 and 590 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 358 and 359 of 1957. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and decree dated April 4, 1956, of the Patna High Court in M. J. C. Nos. 546 and 590 of 1955.

facts.text: On October 8, 1954, by Notification No. III DI-1602 /54-L-15225, the government of Bihar referred an industrial dispute between the management of the Bata Shoe Co. Ltd., Digbaghat Patna, and their 31 workmen to an industrial tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: On October 8, 1954, by Notification No. III DI-1602 /54-L-15225, the government of Bihar referred an industrial dispute between the management of the Bata Shoe Co. Ltd., Digbaghat  Patna , and their 31 workmen, mentioned in annexure I A, in exercise of the powers conferred on the said government by s. 7 read with s. 10 1  of the Act.

facts.text: The first reference was Reference No. 10 of 1954 with Mr. Ali Hassan as the sole member of the tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: For the adjudication of this dispute, an industrial tribunal with Mr. Ali Hassan as the sole member was constituted. This was reference No. 10 of 1954.

facts.text: On January 15,1955, by Notification No. III DI-1601/55 L. 696, the government of Bihar referred another industrial dispute between Bata Shoe Co. and 29 workmen to the same tribunal, Reference No. I of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Then, on January 15,1955, by Notification No. III DI-1601/55 L. 696, a similar industrial dispute between the same Bata Company and its 29 other workmen was referred by the government of Bihar to the same tribunal. This was reference No. I of 1955.

facts.text: On September 17, 1955, by Notification No. III Di-1601/55-L-13028, the government of Bihar purported to supersede the two earlier notifications, combine the disputes, add Bata Mazdoor Union, and refer to the tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: While the proceedings in respect of the two references, which had been consolidated by the tribunal, were pending before it and had made some progress, the government of Bihar issued a third Notification No. III Di-1601/55-L-13028 on September 17, 1955, by which it purported to supersede the two earlier notifications...

facts.text: The superseding notification referred the dispute: Whether the dismissal of the 60 workmen, mentioned in annexure B, was justified or unjustified and to what relief, if any, those workmen are entitled.

anchor.surface_text: The dispute thus referred to the tribunal was, Whether the dismissal of the 60 workmen, mentioned in annexure B, was justified or unjustified and to what relief, if any, those workmen are entitled ?

facts.text: On September 19, 1955, the tribunal passed an order cancelling the hearing of the two prior references fixed for October 3, 1955, and directing the files to be closed.

anchor.surface_text: On receipt of this notification, the tribunal passed an order on September 19, 1955, cancelling the hearing of the two prior references which had been fixed for October 3, 1955, and directing that the files of the said references should be closed.

facts.text: Bata Company and its workmen filed two applications before Patna High Court under articles 226 and 227: M. J. C. Nos. 546 and 590 of 1955, praying to quash the September 17, 1955 notification.

anchor.surface_text: The Bata Company and its workmen then filed two separate applications before the High Court of Judicature at Patna under articles 226 and 227 of the Constitution and prayed that the last notification should be quashed as being illegal and ultra vires. These two applications were numbered as M. J. C. Nos. 546 and 590 of 1955 respectively.

facts.text: On April 4, 1956, Patna High Court held that Bihar government had no power to supersede earlier notifications, allowed the applications, issued certiorari quashing the September 17 notification and mandamus to tribunal to proceed with prior references.

anchor.surface_text: On April 4, 1956, the High Court held that the government of Bihar had no power or authority to supersede the earlier notifications, allowed both the applications and issued a writ in the nature of certiorari quashing the impugned notification of September 17, 1955, and also a writ in the nature of mandamus requiring the industrial tribunal to proceed expeditiously with reference-cases Nos. 10 of 1954 and I of 1955...

facts.text: State of Bihar obtained leave from Supreme Court on June 26, 1956 to appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Against this order the government of Bihar applied for and obtained leave from this Court on June 26, 1956.

facts.text: Workmen of Bata Shoe Co. factory at Digha formed a union at the close of the last World War, president Mr. John, general secretary Mr. Fateh Narain Singh.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the workmen of the company's factory at Digha formed a union at the close of the last World War. The president of the said union was Mr. John and its general secretary was Mr. Fateh Narain Singh.

facts.text: On June 22, 1947, Bata Shoe Co. entered into a collective agreement with the union, settling Standing Orders certified under 1946 Act by mutual consent.

anchor.surface_text: On June 22, 1947, the company entered into a collective agreement with the said union and by mutual consent the Standing Orders and Rules, certified under the Industrial Employment Standing Orders Act of 1946, were settled.

facts.text: Towards end of 1954, two groups formed in union: one led by Mr. Fateh Narain Singh, other by Mr. Bari.

anchor.surface_text: Towards the end of 1954, two groups of the union were formed and rivalry grew between them. One group was led by Mr. Fateh Narain Singh and other by Mr. Bari.

facts.text: On January 22, 1954, union through Mr. Fateh Narain Singh served slowdown notice effective February 24, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: On January 22, 1954, the union through its general secretary Mr. Fateh Narain Singh served on the company a slow down notice with effect from February 24, 1954...

facts.text: On February 6, 1954, Mr. Bari asked followers to strike from February 23, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: ...and on February 6, 1954, Mr. Bari purporting to act as the president of the union asked his followers to go on strike as from February 23, 1954.

facts.text: Some workmen including 60 in question went on illegal strike on February 23, 1954, despite settlement on February 8, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: In spite of the said settlement some workmen, including the sixty workmen in question who supported Mr. Bari, went on an illegal strike on February 23, 1954, although as members of the union they were bound by the settlement.

facts.text: Strike declared illegal by appellant (Bihar Govt) under s. 23(c) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The strike was declared illegal by the appellant under s. 23 c  of the Act.

facts.text: Company dismissed 274 workmen including the 60 in question after charge-sheets.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently, the company served the strikers with charge-sheets and in the end, 274 workmen, including the sixty workmen in question, were dismissed from service by the company.

facts.text: Union negotiated with company; agreed 110 strikers employed, 30 remain dismissed, 30 cases for later reemployment.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the union entered into negotiations with the company, as a result of which it was agreed that 110 strikers would be employed by the company in the same manner in which 76 strikers had already been employed by it. It was further agreed that 30 strikers were to remain dismissed and considered eligible for employment or for any benefits. In regard to the remaining 30 strikers, the company agreed to consider their cases later on for reemployment.

facts.text: The 60 workmen did not demand reinstatement during negotiations.

anchor.surface_text: During these negotiations, the sixty workmen in question did not make any demand to the management for reinstatement either individually or collectively.

facts.text: On September 3, 1954, Conciliation Officer Mr. Sinha wrote to company desiring conciliation for some dismissed workmen.

anchor.surface_text: Notwithstanding this agreement, Mr. Sinha, the conciliation officer, wrote to the company on September 3, 1954, that he desired to hold conciliation proceedings inrespectof,some of the dismissed workmen.

facts.text: Union secretary objected on September 22, 1954 to reference of 60 workmen's dispute.

anchor.surface_text: In fact the secretary of the union wrote to the Commissioner of Labour on September 22, 1954, that he strongly objected to the alleged dispute of sixty workmen being referred to adjudication.

facts.text: On May 30, 1955, union applied to tribunal that majority opposed reinstatement of 60 workmen.

anchor.surface_text: On May 30, 1955, the union made an application before the tribunal alleging that the majority of the workmen were opposed to the reinstatement of the sixty workmen in question and consequently it had interest in the proceedings before the tribunal.

facts.text: Mr. Fateh Narain Singh moved Dept of Labour, Bihar, leading to third notification.

anchor.surface_text: It would appear that Mr. Fateh Narain Singh then moved the Department of Labour Government of Bihar, and it was apparently pursuant to the representation made by him that the third notification was issued by the appellant...

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on August 22, 1958 by GAJENDRAGADKAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. August 22. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by 1193 GAJENDRAGADKAR J.

facts.text: Out of 854 workmen, nearly 500 attended factory despite strike threats.

anchor.surface_text: The strike succeeded only partially because out of 854 workmen employed in the company's factory at Digha nearly 500 workmen attended the factory in spite of the threats of the strikers.

facts.text: On February 16, 1954, letter signed by 500 workmen dis-associating from strike received by company.

anchor.surface_text: The majority of the workmen were opposed to the strike and in fact on February 16, 1954, a letter signed by 500 workmen who dis-associated themselves from the strike, was received by the company.

facts.text: Appellant is State of Bihar, respondents are Bata Company and its workmen.

anchor.surface_text: In both the appeals, the appellant is the State of Bihar and. the respondents are the Bata Company and its workmen respectively.

issues.text: Where an industrial dispute has been referred to a tribunal for adjudication by the appropriate government under s. 10 1 d of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, XIV of 1947 , can the said government supersede the said reference pending adjudication before the tribunal constituted for that purpose ?

anchor.surface_text: GAJENDRAGADKAR J.-Where an industrial dispute has been referred to a tribunal for adjudication by the appropriate government under s. 10 1 d of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 , XIV of 1947 , can the said government supersede the said reference pending adjudication before the tribunal cons

issues.text: the question whether or not it applies to the provisions of a particular statute would depend on the subject-matter, context, and the effect, of the relevant provision, of the said statute

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that this section embodies a rule of construction and the question whether or not it applies to the provisions of a particular statute would depend on the subject-matter, context, and the effect, of the relevant provision, of the said statute. In other words it would be necessary to examine carefully the scheme of the Act, its object and all its relevant and material provisions before deciding whether by the application of the rule of construction enunciated by s. 21, the appellants contention is justified that the power to cancel the reference made under s. 10 1 can be said to vest in the appropriate government by necessary implication.

holdings.text: The appropriate government cannot supersede or cancel a reference made under s. 10(1) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, once proceedings have commenced before the tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: it does not expressly confer any power on the appropriate government to cancel or supersede a reference made under s. 10 1  of the Act. He,-however, argues that the power

holdings.reasoning_summary: No express power; implied power rejected as inconsistent with scheme of ID Act including ss.20(3), 10(5), 17, 19, 33; status quo maintained during pendency; legislature would have provided if intended.

holdings.text: Section 21 of the General Clauses Act does not apply to empower cancellation of reference under s.10(1) ID Act as repugnant to its scheme, context and effect.

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that this section embodies a rule of construction and the question whether or not it applies to the provisions of a particular statute would depend on the subject-matter, context, and the effect, of the relevant provision, of the said statute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule of construction examined against object of industrial peace, adjudication machinery, finality of awards, and specific provisions leaving jurisdiction to tribunal post-reference.

holdings.text: The notification issued by the State of Bihar on September 17, 1955, superseding earlier references is invalid and ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, confirm the finding made by the learned judges of the High Court at Patna, that the notification issued by the appellant cancelling the first two notifications is invalid and ultra vires.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of holdings on lack of power to s.10(1) reference; confirms Patna High Court.

holdings.text: Bona fides of the government cannot validate an act done without statutory authority.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the bona fides of the appellant on which reliance is placed by Dr. Banerjee are really not relevant for determining the appellants powers under s. 10 1  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: If no authority exists, motives irrelevant; only relevant if power challenged on mala fides.

holdings.text: Industrial tribunal can record an amicable settlement between parties and make award in terms thereof, despite no specific provision like CPC O. XXIII r.3.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the Act does not contain any provision specifically authorising the industrial tribunal to record a compromise and pass an award in its terms corresponding

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consistent with Act's object of promoting settlements for industrial peace; tribunals have made such awards; counters need for cancellation.

holdings.text: Minerva Mills Ltd. does not support government's power to cancel reference under s.10(1), as no cancellation occurred; merely new tribunal appointed after expiry.

anchor.surface_text: For the appellant Dr. Bannerjee has strongly relied on the decision of this Court in Minerva Mills Ltd. v. Their Workmen 1 . He contends that Mahajan J...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished on facts: original s.10 orders intact, first tribunal ceased to exist.

precedents.citation: Minerva Mills Ltd. v. Their Workmen 1 [1954 S.C.R. 465]

anchor.surface_text: For the appellant Dr. Bannerjee has strongly relied on the decision of this Court in Minerva Mills Ltd. v. Their Workmen 1 . He contends that Mahajan J. who delivered the judgment of the Court, has expressly observed in his judgment that from the relevant provisions of the Act it could not be held that it was implicit in s. 7 that the government could not withdraw a dispute referred to a tribunal or make the appointment of a tribunal for a limited period of time.

precedents.case_name: Minerva Mills Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: appropriate government has implied power to withdraw a pending reference from one tribunal and refer it to another

precedents.citation: Strawboard Manufacturing Co. Ltd. v. Gutta Mill Workers Union 1 [1953 S.C.R. 439]

anchor.surface_text: The decision of this Court in Strawboard Manufacturing Co. Ltd. v. Gutta Mill Workers Union 1 , is then cited in support of the proposition that the appellant has implied power to cancel its order made, under s. 10 1 .

precedents.case_name: Strawboard Manufacturing Co. Ltd. v. Gutta Mill Workers Union
precedents.cited_proposition: State Government should have cancelled the previous notification and issued a fresh notification referring all issues

precedents.citation: The Textile Workers Union, Amritsar v. The State of Punjab and others 1 [A.I.R. 1957 Pun. 255]

anchor.surface_text: The third decision to which reference has been made in support of the appellants case is the decision of Bishan Narain J. in The Textile Workers Union, Amritsar v. The State of Punjab and others 1 . Bishan Narain J. appears to have taken the view that the power to cancel an order of reference made under s. 10 1 can be implied by invoking s. 21 of the General Clauses Act

precedents.case_name: The Textile Workers Union, Amritsar v. The State of Punjab and others
precedents.cited_proposition: power to cancel reference under s.10(1) implied via s.21 General Clauses Act to preserve industrial peace

precedents.citation: Iyyappen Mills Private Ltd., Trichur v. State of Travancore-Cochin 1 [1958 1 L.L.J. 50]

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the Kerala High Court in Iyyappen Mills Private Ltd., Trichur v. State of Travancore-Cochin 1 , is not of much assistance because in this case the learned judges appear to have taken the view that the first tribunal before which the industrial dispute was pending had ceased to exist at the material time when the dispute was referred by the local government for adjudication to the second tribunal.

precedents.case_name: Iyyappen Mills Private Ltd., Trichur v. State of Travancore-Cochin
precedents.cited_proposition: government can refer dispute to second tribunal if first has ceased to exist

precedents.citation: Harendranath Bose v. Second Industrial Tribunal 3 [1958 11 L.L.J. 198]

anchor.surface_text: Then, in regard to the observations made by Sinha J. in Harendranath Bose v. Second Industrial Tribunal 3 , it is clear that the learned judge was in error in seeking to support his view that the appropriate government can cancel its order made under s. 10 1 by the observations found in the judgment of this Court in Strawboard Manufacturing Co. Ltd. 4 .

precedents.case_name: Harendranath Bose v. Second Industrial Tribunal
precedents.cited_proposition: appropriate government can cancel order under s.10(1)

precedents.citation: South India Estate Labour Relations Organisation v. The State of Madras 5 [A.I.R. 1955 Mad. 45]

anchor.surface_text: The last case to which reference must be made is the decision of Rajamannar C. J. and Venkatarama Aiyar J. in South India Estate Labour Relations Organisation v. The State of Madras 5 . In this case the Madras Government had purported to amend the reference made by it under s. 10 of the Act and the validity of this amendment was challenged before the Court.

precedents.case_name: South India Estate Labour Relations Organisation v. The State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: government can amend a reference under s.10

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, confirm the finding made by the learned judges of the High Court at Patna, that the notification issued by the appellant cancelling the first two notifications is invalid and

outcome.relief_summary: Confirmed High Court's finding that the State government's notification superseding the earlier industrial dispute references is invalid and ultra vires
directions: High Court writs upheld in substance requiring tribunal to proceed with original references Nos. 10 of 1954 and 1 of 1955

edges.explanation: Argument claiming notification illegal and ultra vires claims to satisfy conditions for writ of certiorari to quash.
Argument that the last notification should be quashed as illegal and ultra vires, noting High Court and Supreme Court affirmation, supports the holding of invalidity.

anchor.surface_text: tter, comp

edges.explanation: a13 rejects Textile case argument for implied power, supporting h1 by affirming tribunal control post-reference
Argument that specific notification is invalid and ultra vires claims to satisfy grounds for issuance of certiorari.
Argument declaring the September 17, 1955 notification invalid and ultra vires directly supports the identical holding on that notification.
